Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project pursues five major objectives: 1) Increasing the number of STEM students graduating with associate degrees; 2) Increasing the number of STEM students transferring to baccalaureate institutions; 3) Increasing the diversity of STEM majors, graduates and transfers; 4) Increasing the number of STEM majors progressing successfully through gatekeeper STEM sequences; and 5) Decreasing the average time to associates degrees.

In this project, the faculty members in every STEM department revise their curricula to increase active learning and engagement of students. They also participate in RISE student support services. Existing student services are being enhanced to create a core of services specifically in support of STEM majors. A second tier of more expansive services called "STEP It Up!" is being phased in and tested to determine the impacts on student success. The RISE project is also evaluating its program through a rigorous research design.

This project collaborates externally with local high schools and their parent advisory committee to improve academic preparation for STEM students, to recruit women and underrepresented minority students and to increase STEM career awareness. Internally the project works with the existing on-campus Mathematics, Engineering, Science Achievement (MESA) program to recruit and retain underrepresented students in STEM. Dissemination of the experimentally validated successes and lessons learned provides broader impact to the education community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The past decade has seen simultaneous increases in postsecondary tuition, diversity in the U.S. population and demand for a STEM-educated workforce.  Community colleges (CCs) are an underutilized source of first generation and underrepresented students in STEM fields.  Approximately 50% of students who enter STEM fields start at a community college (CC).  However, only a fraction of the federal funding is awarded to CC STEM projects and few studies of STEM undergraduates include CC students. More research is needed on CC STEM students. There is strong evidence that too few STEM-interested students persist to degree attainment and too often under-represented and under-resourced CC students fail to persist in a STEM degree pathway.   

The RiSE (Relationships in Science Education) project, a student-centered, faculty-driven program at Edmonds Community College (EdCC), focused on increasing STEM student success by creating STEM student resources, building an intentional STEM student community and providing wrap-around support (including tutoring, advising, transfer assistance). RiSE is a voluntary student group that all STEM students are invited to join through course announcements, flyers and outreach activities.  A STEM study room is the center of the community, and activities are coordinated by a STEM support specialist staff position. Student support includes peer tutors, faculty participation (office hours, advising and mentoring), service learning and undergraduate research opportunities, speakers and panels, and workshops and application assistance for students transferring to regional colleges and universities.  RiSE events increase STEM student identity, RiSE visibility, administrative buy-in and faculty validation and include STEM student awards, STEM “Kickoffs” for each quarter, a Haunted STEM lab & STEM “magic” show. 

We posed two overarching questions of our seven-year RiSE project: (1) What impact has RiSE had on STEM student persistence, success (GPA) and sense of community?  (2) To what extent have STEM faculty been engaged and impacted by the RiSE program?  We used a mixed methods approach to address these research questions. We analyzed six years of quantitative data on student participation and faculty engagement in RiSE.  We also analyzed student records to quantitatively measure the impact on student performance.  We periodically surveyed students and faculty and analyzed this self-report data.  We used a qualitative phenomenological approach to code and analyze written reflections and semi-structured interviews of faculty.   

Students involved in RiSE have a higher GPA (0.2 higher, Figure 1) and increased persistence (21%, Figure 2) compared to similar STEM students.  The effect of RiSE is critical for our students who are often under-prepared and underprivileged. RiSE students are economically disadvantaged with >30% of these students economically disadvantaged for their entire education at EdCC.  RiSE students persistent, even when they are not successful the first time in lower-level STEM courses.  For example, RiSE students who earn less than a 2.0 in intermediate algebra (a pre-college level math course) are more likely than matched non-RiSE student with a 4.0 in the same class to eventually enroll in the subsequent pre-calculus.  We believe that support from the RiSE project (tutoring, advising, community, etc.) helps students continue toward a STEM degree in spite of early challenges in failing and repeating prerequisite courses.  This is reflected in student surveys, in which RiSE students are 59% more likely to report being part of the EdCC STEM community than are Non-RISE students. 

Although students have been the primary target of this project, faculty have been critical to its success, and faculty communities have been formed.  Faculty have come together in a Core Leadership Team, STEM-based education research Journal Club, and Faculty Colloquium series to discuss research and share best practices in pedagogy and student support. Through student events, undergraduate research, engaged evidence-based instruction, and a STEM Study Room, faculty have become increasingly engaged with students and have built a community that supports all students.  Furthermore, RiSE has prompted faculty from across STEM disciplines to change teaching approaches to include more research-based methods and become more engaged in the STEM community.  Faculty transformation results in changes in students learning and confidence as described in faculty interviews, “because we are not just assessing what students remember or know but also look at what is challenging for them to conceptualize or articulate, students are learning more and gaining confidence in their ability to extrapolate and transfer information.”       

EdCC students go on to earn bachelor’s degrees in STEM disciplines. CC students are a critical source of talent and diversity for 4-year colleges and universities.  RiSE has increased the success and persistence of EdCC STEM students; other institutions also must intentionally support and value CC STEM transfer students to increase their success and persistence in undergraduate and graduate programs. 

For more information, see www.edcc.edu/rise.
